movie.info: Airplane Writers : Jim Abrahams David ZuckerJerry Zucker Genres : ComedyRomance
movie.beginning:
AIRPLANE
Written by
Jim Abrahams, David Zucker & Jerry Zucker
SHOOTING SCRIPT June 11, 1979 Revised 6/15/79

scene.sceneheader: EXT. SKY - JUST ABOVE CLOUDS - NIGHT
scene.meta: OMINOUS, THREATENING MUSIC. The upper tail fin of a jet plane emerges through the cloud layer and PASSES THROUGH the FRAME like a shark's fin through water. It passes by again in the opposite direction. MUSIC BUILDS as the fin comes straight TOWARD the CAMERA, MUSIC SWELLS to CRESCENDO as entire jet plane lifts out of clouds and passes overhead. TITLE SLASHES ACROSS SCREEN, "AIRPLANE!" CREDITS and MUSIC continue over following.
ESTABLISHING terminal building.

scene.sceneheader: EXT. TERMINAL BUILDING - PASSENGER LOADING ZONE - NIGHT
scene.meta: Airport bus arrives. Stewardess ELAINE DICKINSON steps off. CAMERA FOLLOWS Elaine as she walks to terminal building.
scene.dialogue: The white zone is for immediate loading and unloading of passengers only. There is no stopping in the red zone.
The red zone is for immediate loading and unloading of passengers. There is no stopping in the white zone.
No. The white zone is for loading and unloading, and there is no stopping in the red zone.
The red zone has always been for loading and unloading, and there is never stopping in a white zone.
Don't tell me which zone is for stopping and which zone is for loading.
Listen, Betty. Don't start up with your white zone shit again!
scene.meta: Elaine enters terminal building.
Elaine is approached by a religious ZEALOT #1.
scene.dialogue: Hello, we'd like you to have this flower from the Religious Consciousness Church.
No, but thank you very much.
scene.meta: Arrival-Departure TV monitors. Elaine approaches.
scene.dialogue: Reads: Flight 209 to Chicago - Depart Gate 89 - 7:25 p.m. Arrival monitor is goldfish swimming.

She checks her watch and walks past Security Check area. CAMERA STAYS with a middle-aged couple, SHIRLEY and JACK, waiting to pass through Security Check. Behind them is sign reading: WARNING, HIJACKING IS A FEDERAL OFFENSE, etc.
Jack, isn't that Fred Bliffert over there in the blue turtleneck? Maybe he's on our flight to Chicago.
Yeah, I think he is. (waves) Hey, Fred!
scene.meta: FRED recognizes Jack.
scene.dialogue: (yelling) Hi, Jack!!!
scene.meta: A swarm of police and airport security men descend on Fred and take him away.

scene.sceneheader: EXT. AIRPORT - PASSENGER LOADING ZONE - NIGHT
scene.meta: A limousine arrives. Two colorfully dressed BLACK DUDES emerge. An extra pesters them. Two HARE KRISHNA'S arrive on foot and walk toward terminal.
scene.dialogue: There's just no stopping in the white zone.
Christ, you're as bad as your mother!
Oh, really, Vernon! Why pretend? We both know perfectly well what it is you're talking about. You want me to have an abortion.
It's really the only sensible thing to do. If it's done properly, therapeutically, there's no danger involved.
Have you considered that what's inside me is a human being; that it's alive. We made love. It's us -- you and me.
That isn't true. A fetus at this stage is not a human being, nor is it a person.
scene.meta: Krishnas enter terminal building.
The Krishnas are approached by the Religious Zealot.
scene.dialogue: Hello, we'd like you to have this flower from the Church of Consciousness. Would you like to make a donation?
(shakes his head) No, we gave at the office.

scene.meta: A voluptuous BLONDE saunters through the airport, clears her throat loudly, and spits on the wall. She walks past an ELDERLY WOMAN standing outside a men's room door. She turns and sticks her head in the door.
scene.dialogue: Go, O.J., go!!

scene.meta: SECURITY CHECK LADY is watching X-ray scanner. First picture is typically filled suitcase, then another, then a chest X- ray. A man passes through metal detector archway and it BEEPS.
scene.dialogue: Please put your metal objects on this tray.
scene.meta: He puts his watch, keys on the tray. Then removes his metal arm and metal leg.

scene.sceneheader: EXT. TERMINAL BUILDING - PASSENGER LOADING AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: MR. and MRS. HAMMEN and their eight year old son, JOEY, arrive in a station wagon. They unload luggage.
scene.dialogue: The red zone is for immediate loading and unloading of passengers only. There is no stopping in the white zone.
scene.meta: P.A. System Female v.o. weeping.
scene.dialogue: The red zone is for...Betty, put down that gun!
scene.meta: SHOTS and GROAN.
scene.dialogue: The white zone is for immediate loading and unloading of passengers only. There is no stopping in the red zone.
scene.meta: The Hammens walk toward terminal past a BUSINESSMAN.
scene.dialogue: Taxi!
scene.meta: A taxi cab skids to a stop in front of him. The Businessman gets in as the driver, TED STRIKER, drops the flag and rushes out.
scene.dialogue: Back in a minute.

scene.sceneheader: INT. TERMINAL BUILDING - BAGGAGE PICKUP AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Striker enters, looking around as if searching for someone. People are rolling down the conveyor belt of a baggage carousel, banging into each other like luggage. The luggage is standing around the conveyor belt, waiting for the people to come off.

scene.sceneheader: INT. TERMINAL BUILDING - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Striker, walking briskly, is approached by Zealot #3 who tries to pin a flower on his jacket. Striker keeps walking but the Zealot is persistent. Finally, Striker slips out of his jacket leaving the Zealot with the coat.
scene.dialogue: Your attention, please. Flight seven- thirty-three from Milwaukee is now arriving on the B Concourse, Gate thirty- five.

scene.meta: Flight 733 taxis toward gate. A GROUND CREWMAN with red flashlights is directing plane to his right. A SECOND GROUND CREWMAN approaches as First Ground Crewman continues to direct plane to his right. CREDITS END.
scene.dialogue: Hey, Joe, where's the forklift?
The forklift? It's over there by the baggage loader.
scene.meta: He points to the left with his flashlights. Flight 733 follows flashlights and CRASHES into terminal.
Nose of Flight 733 CRASHES into terminal, scattering waiting crowd. A woman tosses away her infant child as she runs off.

scene.sceneheader: INT. TERMINAL BULIDING - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Striker catches up to Elaine.
scene.dialogue: Elaine!
(surprised) Ted!
I came home early and found your note. I guess you meant for me to read it later. Elaine, I've got to talk to you.
I just don't want to go over it any more.
I know things haven't been right for a long time, but it'll be different. If you'll just be patient, I can work things out.
I have been patient and I've tried to help, but you wouldn't even let me do that.
Don't you feel anything for me at all any more?
It takes so many things to make love last. Most of all it takes respect. And I can't live with a man I don't respect!
scene.meta: She leaves.
scene.dialogue: (to CAMERA) What a pisser.

scene.sceneheader: INT. TERMINAL BUILDING - CONCESSION AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: CAPTAIN CLARENCE OVEUR is standing at the magazine racks. The first two sections of the display are books; the third is girly magazines. The captions over the dis­play are FICTION, NON-FICTION, WHACKING MATERIAL. He selects a magazine entitled "Modern Sperm" and begins to page through.
scene.dialogue: Captain Clarence Oveur, white courtesy phone. Captain Clarence Oveur, white courtesy phone.
scene.meta: Captain Oveur approaches telephones and picks up a red phone.
scene.dialogue: No, the white phone.
scene.meta: Oveur picks up the white phone.
scene.dialogue: This is Captain Oveur.
One moment for your call from the Mayo Clinic.
Captain Oveur, white courtesy phone. Captain Clarence Oveur...
(yelling at ceiling) I've got it!
All right. Thank you.
Go ahead with your call.
This is Doctor Turnansky at the Mayo Clinic.

scene.meta: DR. TURNANSKY is seated at desk. Behind him are shelves filled with mayonnaise jars.
scene.dialogue: There's a passenger on your Chicago flight two-oh-niner, a little girl named Lisa Davis -- en route to Minneapolis. She's scheduled for a heart transplant and we'd like you to tell her mother that we found a donor an hour ago.
scene.meta: On his desk is a beaker containing a beating heart.
scene.dialogue: We have the heart here ready for surgery and we must have the recipient on the operating table within six hours.
scene.meta: The heart jumps out of the beaker, across the desk and falls off the edge.
scene.dialogue: I want you to make sure she is kept in a reclined position and that a continuous watch is kept on her I.V.

scene.sceneheader: INT. TERMINAL BUILDING - PHONE AREA - NIGHT
scene.dialogue: Also, it's important that...
Excuse me. This is the Operator, Captain Oveur, I have an emergency call for you on line five trom a Mister Hamm.
All right. Give me Hamm on five, hold the Mayo.

scene.meta: Ambulance arrives at airplane. Attendants and MRS. DAVIS unload LISA DAVIS into wheelchair.
Elaine and Striker are walking together.
scene.dialogue: Look, you'll be back in town tomorrow night. We'll have dinner -- talk it over.
I won't be back. I've requested the Atlanta run.
Elaine, not yet. I promise you I really can change.
Then why don't you take the job that Louie Netz offered you at Boeing?
scene.meta: In the b.g. an airline PORTER is transporting an ELDERLY COUPLE in an electric cart. They round the corner too fast and the woman falls out. Husband doesn't notice.
scene.dialogue: You know I haven't been able to get near an airplane since the war. And even if I could, they wouldn't hire me because of my war record.
Your war record? You're the only one keeping that alive. For everyone else it's ancient history.
You expect me to believe that?
scene.meta: In the b.g. the Elderly Woman staggers to her feet and is immediately run over by another electric cart.
scene.dialogue: It's the truth. What's hurt you the most is your record since the war. Different cities, different jobs, and not one of them shows you can accept any real responsibility.
But if you'll just give me...
It's too late, Ted. When I get back to Chicago, I'm going to start my life all over again. I'm sorry.
scene.meta: She walks off. Dramatic MUSIC as Striker glares with determination. The religious Zealot tries to pin a flower on his lapel.
scene.dialogue: Hello, we'd like you to have this...
scene.meta: Without looking, Striker decks the Zealot with one punch. He walks after Elaine.
Clarence Oveur is in the pilot's seat. VICTOR BASTA is seated at engineer's console. There is a St. Christopher's statue on the dashboard.
scene.dialogue: Any word on that storm lifting over Salt Lake, Clarence?
scene.meta: TEXACO SERVICE MAN is cleaning windshield.
scene.dialogue: Unlikely, Victor. I just reviewed the Area Report for 1609 hours through 2400 hours. That's an occluded front stalled over the Dakotas -- backed up all the way to Utah.
scene.meta: Texaco Service Man opens hood and checks dipstick.
scene.dialogue: If it decides to push over into the Great Lakes it could get plenty soupy. How about the southern route, around Tulsa?
I double checked the terminal forecast and winds aloft. IFR ceilings all the way.
scene.meta: Oveur gives charge card to Texaco Man.
scene.dialogue: Where do they top out?
Well, there's some light scattered cover at twenty thousand with icing around eighteen.
Looks like the original flight plan over Denver is still the best bet.
scene.meta: Oveur signs charge form and gives it to Texaco Man.
scene.dialogue: Denver it is.
scene.meta: ROGER MURDOCK enters. He is played by a famous athlete.
scene.dialogue: Sorry, Clarence. Latest weather report shows everything socked in from Salt Lake to Lincoln.
(to Murdock) Hi, Roger. Good to have you aboard. Victor, this is Roger Murdock.
How do you do, Roger?
scene.meta: Texaco Man hands receipt to Oveur.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - BOARDING AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Stewardesses Elaine and RANDY are greeting boarding passengers including the Hammens and SISTER ANGELINA who is carrying a guitar.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.dialogue: Do you believe those goddamn Steelers? Can you imagine blitzing on third and long with two minutes in the game?
Well, hell, they couldn't stay in zone coverage with Dallas running swing patterns!

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.dialogue: What did you think of 'Great Expectations?'
Well, it wasn't all that I had hoped.

scene.meta: A SOLDIER and GIRL are tearfully embracing at the base of the stairs leading into the plane.
scene.dialogue: Oh, Bill, I'm going to miss you so much.
You promise you'll write.
Every day.
Better get on board, son.

scene.meta: Striker approaches check-in counter.
scene.dialogue: Can you tell me if Elaine Dickinson is on this flight?
scene.meta: She looks at her list.
scene.dialogue: Well, the whole flight crew has boarded. Yes. She is on board.
I'd like one ticket to Chicago. No baggage!

scene.sceneheader: EXT. TERMINAL BUILDING - PASSENGER LOADING AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: The Businessman is patiently waiting in Striker's cab.

scene.dialogue: Smoking or non-smoking?
Smoking, please.
scene.meta: She hands him a smoldering ticket, and he walks out the door.
Striker emerges and freezes in terror.
scene.dialogue: DRAMATIC MUSIC.
agonizing over war recollections. SUPERIMPOSE ROARING fighter planes. SUPER FADES OUT. Striker musters his courage and walks toward airplane.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: BLACK DUDE #l Shi',man, tha' honkey mo'fo' mess wi' my ol' lady, man I rap tha' dude upside his head, man.
SUBTITLES APPEAR ON SCREEN: "GOLLY, THAT WHITE FELLOW SHOULD
STAY AWAY FROM MY WIFE OR I WILL PUNCH HIM."
scene.dialogue: Yeah, man, he ain't never goin' come on layin' no pig rap off you, man.
scene.meta: SUBTITLES APPEAR ON SCREEN: "YES, THERE IS TRUTH IN WHAT YOU
SAY. HOWEVER, I THINK HE MAY BE MISLEADING YOU."

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Randy is taking Striker's ticket.
scene.dialogue: Fourteen-B. It's halfway down on your right.
Thank you.
scene.meta: As Striker sits down he sees Elaine, who is unaware he is on board.
scene.dialogue: Elaine is handing out pillows. We HEAR A DING.
"NO SMOKING
"FASTEN SEAT BELTS
He fastens his seat belt and looks nervously out the window. The Elderly Woman next to him notices.
Nervous?
Yes.
First time?
No. I've been nervous lots of times. I used to be a pilot myself...during the war.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Elaine approaches Mrs. Davis and Lisa.
scene.dialogue: We'll be taking off real soon so we better fasten you in tight.
Thank you. Oh Mother, this is so exciting.
I know, but remember you must get some rest.
That's good advice. You relax and I'll be back after we take off.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: MILTON, an eight year old boy wearing a conservative coat and tie, fastens his seat belt and begins reading his "Business Monthly" magazine. He sees BERNICE, a seven year old girl, in the aisle and looks her up and down.
DRAMATIC MUSIC. Engines one and two REV UP.
Murdock and Oveur look toward left wing.
ENGINES three and four REV UP.
Murdock and Oveur look toward right wing.
Two more ENGINES REV UP.
Murdock and Oveur look toward left wing and do a double take.
Two more ENGINES REV UP.
Murdock and Oveur are confused and counting on their fingers.
Stairs are removed from airplane. The Soldier is in the open doorway waving good-bye to his tearful girlfriend at the base of the plane.

scene.dialogue: Two-zero-niner to ground control. We are loaded and ready to taxi.
Roger, two-zero-niner. You are third in line for takeoff...Air Israel, taxi into position.

scene.meta: An Air Israel airplane with beard and pais, wearing a yarmulka and tallis.

scene.dialogue: Air Poland, you are cleared for takeoff.

scene.meta: Crew is Jose Feliciano and look-alike for Ray Charles.

scene.dialogue: Taxi to runway one-niner.

scene.meta: Oveur moves console levers as if shifting into first gear.
as 209 starts to taxi, the Soldier is leaning out the door.
scene.dialogue: Good-bye, darling.

scene.meta: His girlfriend is moving along next to the plane as in typical train station good-bye scene.
scene.dialogue: Oh, good-bye, Bill! Have your picture taken as soon as you get there and send me one!
scene.meta: As she runs, she dodges posts. We HEAR the chug chug of a steam engine pulling from a station.
scene.dialogue: I will.
scene.meta: She runs through crowd of people standing on side of runway.
scene.dialogue: Don't you go getting fat or anything.
scene.meta: She's running faster.
scene.dialogue: Don't worry, I won't. Okay, here -- hurry!
scene.meta: He tosses her his watch.
scene.dialogue: Oh, but it's your watch. You shouldn't. You'll need it.
scene.meta: She is now knocking down posts as she keeps up with the accelerating plane.
scene.dialogue: Good-bye, darling.
Oh, Bill, I'll keep it. I'll keep it with me all the time.
So long, darling. Good-bye. Take care of yourself.
Bill! Bill! Good-bye, Bill.
Good-bye, darling.
Good-bye, darling. I love you. I love you, darling.
Good-bye, darling.
scene.meta: A TRAIN WHISTLE sounds. She stops running and waves.

scene.dialogue: Flight two-zero-niner, you are cleared for takeoff.
Roger.
(turning to Oveur) Huh?
scene.meta: Oveur throws console lever into second gear.
scene.dialogue: L.A. departure frequency two-point-niner.
Roger.
(turning to Oveur) Huh?
(to tower) Request vector...over.
(turning to Basta) What?
Flight two-zero-niner, cleared for vector three...two four.
We have clearance, Clarence.
Roger, Roger. What's our vector, Victor?
scene.meta: Oveur throws console lever into third.
Flight 209 takes off, flying erratically.
scene.dialogue: Tower radioed clearance, over.
That's Clarence Oveur...over.
Roger.
Huh?
Roger, over.
What?!
Huh?

dialogue.name: INSERT - SEAT BELT AND SMOKING SIGNS

scene.dialogue: going off.

scene.meta: Striker walks to rear of plane and looks out window. He swallows a couple of pills. Randy approaches.
scene.dialogue: Do you feel all right, sir?
Oh -- I haven't flown for a long time.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Elaine is handing out magazines.
scene.dialogue: Good evening, this is Captain Oveur speaking. We'll be cruising at thirty-six, thousand feet, and arrival time in Chicago is ten-forty-five Central Time. The temperature there is sixty-two degrees, with a twenty percent chance of precipitation. And now here's Victor with People in the news.
Thank you, Clarence. Ali McGraw announced another spin on the marriage-go-round. And who's the lucky guy? You guessed it. None other than Olympic gymnast...
scene.meta: Elaine approaches Mrs. Elderly. Striker's seat is vacant.
scene.dialogue: Would you like something to read?
Do you have anything light?
scene.meta: Elaine hands her a small piece of paper.
scene.dialogue: How about this leaflet: 'Famous Jewish Sports Legends?'
(taking pamphlet) Yes. Thank you.
scene.meta: Elaine turns and is shocked to see Striker approaching his seat.
scene.dialogue: Ted, what are you doing here?
Elaine, I've got to talk to you.
You...you shouldn't have come. I don't have time now.
Oh, stewardess...
Excuse me.
scene.meta: Striker sits down.
scene.dialogue: No wonder you're upset. She's lovely. And a darling figure. Supple, pouting breasts. Firm thighs. It's a shame you're not getting along.
Yes, I know. Things used to be different. I remember when we first met. It was during the war.

scene.meta: Striker is seated at bar in a smoke-filled room. An assortment of unsavory characters are hanging around the bar.
scene.dialogue: I was in the Air Force, stationed in Drambuie, on the Barbary Coast. I used to hang out in the Magumba Bar.
scene.meta: Shapely female legs walking on bar stop in front of Striker. SLEAZY TROMBONE MUSIC. CAMERA PANS UP shapely female in tight fitting dress. She is play­ing the sleazy trombone music.
scene.dialogue: It was a rough place. You would count on a fight breaking out almost every night.
scene.meta: Two GIRL SCOUTS are slugging it out old Western style -- breaking tables and chairs.

scene.sceneheader: INT. MAGUMBA BAR - JUKEBOX AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: An unsavory CHARACTER puts a quarter in the jukebox. One Girl Scout bashes the other against the jukebox buttons.
scene.dialogue: DISCO TUNE plays. Girl Scout is bashed against juke­box again.
Girl Scout bashes again.
The unsavory Character nods approvingly at selections.

scene.sceneheader: INT. MAGUMBA BAR DANCE FLOOR - NIGHT
scene.meta: Patrons are dancing a la John Travolta.
scene.dialogue: I didn't go there that night to fall in love, I just dropped in for a couple of drinks.
He turns to look toward dance floor.
But suddenly there she was.
Elaine dancing with grizzly looking cutthroat.
I was captivated, entranced.
scene.meta: BACK TO STRIKER
scene.dialogue: It hit me like a thunderbolt. I had to ask the guy next to me to pinch me to make sure I wasn't dreaming.
scene.meta: Striker asks the burly LONGSHOREMAN next to him to to pinch him. Longshoreman gives him a look and moves away cautiously.
scene.dialogue: I was afraid to approach her, but that night, fate was on my side.
scene.meta: Elaine's dancing partner is stabbed in the back and falls to the grould. No one notices but Striker who eagerly fills in. They make a perfect disco couple. The other dancers make a circle around them. They begin with fancy disco steps, move on to flips and seemingly impossible acrobatics, finally ending with incredible stunts: Striker, jumping through flaming hoops and Elaine, hanging from a chandelier by her teeth and twirling.

scene.sceneheader: INT. MAGUMBA BAR DANCE FLOOR - NIGHT
scene.meta: Bar is closing, chairs on tables, bartender sweeping floor, Elaine and Striker dancing slowly in center of room. One final Girl Scout flies into FRAME and falls in a lifeless heap at their feet.

scene.dialogue: We laughed, we talked, we danced, I never wanted it to end and I guess I still don't. But enough about me. I hope this hasn't been boring for you.
scene.meta: CAMERA WIDENS to reveal Mrs. Elderly's legs dangling next to him. She has hung herself.
scene.dialogue: It's just that when I start to talk about Elaine, I get so carried away -- I lose all track of time -- not unlike Oliver in 'Jesus: the Man.'

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Milton, carrying a tray with two cups of coffee, approaches Bernice.
scene.dialogue: I happened to be passing, and I thought you might like some corfee.
That's very nice of you. Thank you.
scene.meta: She takes a cup.
scene.dialogue: Ah, won't you sit down?
Thank you. Cream?
No, thank you. I take it black. Like my men.
Were you vacationing in Los Angeles?
Well, it really wasn't a vacation. You see, I'm a teacher in the New York City school system, and I was attending a seminar on visual aids to education. Are you from L.A.?
No. I'm from Washington, D.C. I'm a lobbyist for the Small Businessmen's Assocation.

scene.meta: Elaine is taking orders from a couple and their eight year old son.
scene.dialogue: Would you like to order dinner now?
Yes. Steak for Joey and my wife and I will have the fish.
When can I see the cockpit, Dad?
Well, I think that the pilots are too busy flying the plane for that, Joey.
Aw, gee whiz.
I tell you what, Joey. I'll talk to the Captain and see what I can arrange.
Gee! That'd be swell!
scene.meta: Elaine moves on to the two Black Dudes.
scene.dialogue: Would you gentlemen care to order your dinners?
scene.meta: The Black Dudes point to their selections on the menu.
scene.dialogue: 'Ey ma' muh fuh wha' fo', shi!
scene.meta: SUBTITLES APPEAR: "I WOULD LIKE THE STEAK, PLEASE."
scene.dialogue: Shi' mo cain ma foh mess wi' ain?!
scene.meta: SUBTITLES APPEAR: "I'LL HAVE THE FISH, THANK YOU."

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Randy is taking dinner orders from Hari Krishnas.
scene.dialogue: May I take your dinner order?
No, thank you, we brought our own vegetables.
But we would like some hot water for our tea, please.
scene.meta: Randy moves on.
scene.dialogue: Did you catch the jugs on that broad?

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - STEWARDESS ALCOVE - NIGHT
scene.meta: Elaine is replacing a magazine and catches sight of Striker.
scene.dialogue: Boring another passenger.
She moves into the alcove and begins to pour coffee. CAMERA MOVES INTO CLOSEUP of Elaine.

scene.meta: Striker and Elaine are running. She falls down at the water's edge, exhausted. Striker drops to his knees and they embrace passionately. A huge wave washes over them covering them completely. When the wave recedes, they're still locked in the same embrace. They are covered with seaweed. Fish are flopping around in the sand.
scene.dialogue: Oh, Ted, I never knew I could be so happy. These past few months have been wonderful. Tomorrow why don't we drive up the coast to that little seafood place and...
scene.meta: Striker frowns.
scene.dialogue: What's the matter?
My orders came through. My squadron ships out tomorrow. I'll be leading a very important mission.
Oh, Ted, please be careful. I worry about you so much.
I love you, Elaine.
I love you.
scene.meta: They embrace. Another huge wave washes in and covers them completely.
Elaine comes back to reality.
In level flight.

scene.dialogue: Flight two-zero-niner, this is Denver Flight Control. You're approaching some rough weather. Please climb to forty-two thousand feet.
Roger, Denver.
scene.meta: There is a KNOCK on the cockpit door. Elaine and Joey enter.
scene.dialogue: We have a visitor.
Hello.
Hi.
This is Captain Oveur. Mister Murdock and Mister Johnson. This is Joey Hammen.
Come on up here. You can see better.
Joey, here's something we give our special visitors. Would you like to have it?
scene.meta: He gives Joey a small toy airplane and puts his arm around him.
scene.dialogue: Thank you. Thanks a lot!
Have you ever been in a cockpit before?
No, sir. I've never been up in a plane before.
Have you ever seen a grown man naked?
Do you want me to check the weather, Clarence?
(looking at Joey) No, why don't you take care ot it?
We'd better get back now.
Joey can stay up here for a while if he'd like to.
Could I?
Okay, if you don't get in the way.
scene.meta: Elaine exits. Murdock picks up phone.
scene.dialogue: Flight two-zero-niner to Denver radio. Climbing to cruise at forty-two thousand. Will report again over Lincoln. Over and out.
scene.meta: Joey has been paying very close attention to Murdock, and suddenly recognizes him.
scene.dialogue: Wait a minute. I know you. You're Kareem Abdul Jabbar. You play basketball for the Los Angeles Lakers!
I'm sorry, son, but you must have me confused with someone else. My name is Roger Murdock. I'm the co-pilot.
scene.meta: He turns to Basta.
scene.dialogue: Ah, Victor, why don't you get the coordinates on the altitude vector and find out the ratio of direct velocity over engine speed?
scene.meta: Victor is puzzled.
scene.dialogue: You are Kareem. I've seen you play. My Dad's got season tickets!
I think you should go back to your seat now, Joey. Right, Clarence?
No, he's not bothering anyone. Let him stay up here.
All right. But just remember, my name is Roger Murdock.
scene.meta: He points to his nametag.
scene.dialogue: I'm an airline pilot. (to Oveur) Ah, Clarence, according to my calculations, with this tailwind we ought to be able to make up an additional fifteen minutes over the Rockies.
I think you're the greatest. But my Dad says you don't work hard enough on defense.
(into microphone) Denver Control, this is Flight two-zero- niner intersecting Victor Airway seven- niner-niner.
...and that lots of times you don't even run down court.
We are turning left to a heading of zero- niner-niner.
...and that you don't really try, except during the playoffs.
The hell I don't! I'm out there busting my buns every night.
scene.meta: Murdock realizes he has given himself away. He quickly looks to see if Oveur is listening. Oveur is busy checking instruments. Murdock grabs Joey by the collar and whispers angrily.
scene.dialogue: Listen, kid, I've been hearing that crap ever since I was at UCLA. Tell your old man to drag Unseld and Lanier up and down the court for forty-eight minutes. (into mike) Ah...Denver Control, this is Flight two- zero-niner continuing on a heading two- niner-niner...niner, ah...niner...niner.

scene.meta: Elaine is seated next to Striker.
scene.dialogue: Elaine, just hear me out. I know things haven't been right for a long time. But it will be different...like it was in the beginning. Remember?
I remember everything. All I have are memories.
scene.meta: Soft MUSIC begins.
scene.dialogue: Mostly I remember...the nights when we were together. I remember how you used to hold me...and how I used to sit on your face and wriggle...and then afterwards how we'd watch until the sun came up. When it did, it was almost like...like each new day was created...only for us.
That's the way I've always wanted it to be, Elaine.
But it won't be. Not as long as you insist on living in the past!
scene.meta: Elaine leaves, teary-eyed.
CLOSEUP - STRIKER
SUPERIMPOSE:
Fighter plane diving.
scene.dialogue: You're too low, Ted! You're too low!
scene.meta: Fighter plane CRASHES.
Sign in front reads:
U.S. ARMY PSYCHIATRIC HOSPITAL
scene.dialogue: Master Charge, Visa, Carte Blanche

scene.meta: Striker is lying in bed painting a canvas. Elaine is seated at bedside.
scene.dialogue: You got a telegram from head­quarters today.
Headquarters!? What is it?
It's a big building where the generals meet. But that's not important right now. They've cleared you of any blame for what happened on that raid. Isn't that good news?
A surreal image of a soldier contorted like a pretzel clutching a machine gun in one hand and a crying infant in the other.
scene.meta: BACK TO HOSPITAL - DAY
scene.dialogue: Is it? Because of my mistake six men didn't return from that raid.
Seven. Lieutenant Zipp died this morning. Ted, Doctor Sandler says you'll be out in a week. Isn't that wonderful?
scene.meta: In the b.g., a doctor in a white lab coat is attending a patient. When he turns around WE SEE he is wearing an STP insignia on his back.
scene.dialogue: I wish I could say the same for George Zipp.
Be patient, Ted. No one expects you to get over this immediately.
scene.meta: Striker is despondent. SGT. McCOBB (o.s.) Hey, Striker!

scene.sceneheader: INT. HOSPITAL - ANGLE - SGT. McCOBB - DAY
scene.meta: He is posing for Striker's painting, contorted like a pretzel, holding a machine gun in one hand and crying baby in the other. SGT. McCOBB How about a break? I'm getting tired!
scene.dialogue: All right. Take five.
scene.meta: McCobb untangles himself and walks off.

scene.dialogue: I found a wonderful apartment for us. It's got a brick fireplace and a cute little bedroom with mirrors on the ceiling. And...
I'm off course. Red Leader!!! Look out!!
That's Captain Geline. He thinks he's a pilot, still fighting the war.

scene.meta: Captain Geline agonizing and making bombing and machine gun noises.

scene.dialogue: Groan.
What's his problem?
That's Lieutennt Hurwitz. Severe shell shock. He thinks he's Ethel Merman.

scene.meta: Strapped to the bed is ETHEL MERMAN singing "EVERYTHING'S COMING UP ROSES." She breaks loose from the straps for a grand finale. Two attendants attempt to restrain her.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - BACK TO STRIKER - NIGHT
scene.dialogue: Excuse me, sir. Would you like some coffee before we serve dinner?
No. No thank you.
scene.meta: Randy moves on to the Hammens.
scene.dialogue: Would either of you like another cup of coffee?
I will, but Jim won't.
Yes, I think I will have another cup of coffee.
scene.meta: CAMERA ZOOMS to CLOSEUP of Mrs. Hammen.
scene.dialogue: Jim never has a second cup of coffee at home.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Randy approaches Sister Angelina. The guitar is on the seat next to her.
scene.dialogue: Excuse me, Sister?
Yes?
There's a little girl on board who's ill and...
Oh yes, I saw. Poor child.
Could I borrow your guitar? I thought I might be able to cheer her up.
Of course.
scene.meta: Randy takes the guitar and walks down the aisle. The guitar clonks people on the back of the head. Randy approaches Lisa.
scene.dialogue: Is it all right if I talk to your daughter?
Oh, I think that would be nice.
(to Lisa, who is reading) Hi!
Hi!
I'm Randy.
I'm Lisa. Oh, you have a guitar!
I thought maybe you'd like to hear a song.
Oh, I'd love to.
Okay, this is one of my favorites.
scene.meta: Randy is sitting on the edge of the gurney as she strums three opening chords.
scene.dialogue: (strumming and singing in ballad tempo) 'I've traveled the banks of the River Jordan, to find where it flows to the sea.'
scene.meta: Stewardesses and passengers notice the singer and peer around corners and over seat backs. A man's head peers upside down from the TOP OF THE FRAME.
scene.dialogue: 'I looked in the eyes of the cold and the hungry and saw that I was looking at me.'
scene.meta: As singing continues, Shirley and Jack look at each other with saccherine smiles, the Hammens do the same, then the Krishnas, then the Black Dudes. Finally, everyone is smiling sweetly at each other.
Murdock and Oveur smile sweetly at each other...

scene.dialogue: (singing and playing the guitar) 'And I wanted to know if life had a purpose, and what it all means in the end. In the silence I listened to the voices inside me, and they told me again and again.'
scene.meta: Tempo Jumps to rock pace.
scene.dialogue: 'There is only one river. There is only one sea.'
scene.meta: Randy, in her growing enthusiasm, swings her guitar, knocking the I.V. connection tube from Lisa's arm. The I.V. squirts, and Lisa turns pale and hollow­cheeked. No one else notices.
scene.dialogue: 'And it flows through you, and it flows through me. There is only one people, we are one and the same.'
scene.meta: Lisa manages to reconnect her I.V.
scene.dialogue: (still singing) 'We are all one spirit, one name. We are the Father, we are the son.'
scene.meta: Randy again knocks I.V. from Lisa's arm with guitar as the passengers start to get into the music.
scene.dialogue: 'In the Dawn of Creation. We are one.'
scene.meta: Mrs. Davis rushes to reconnect Lisa's I.V. Lisa doesn't react. Mrs. Davis pounds Lisa's chest.
scene.dialogue: 'We are only one people, we are one and the same.'
scene.meta: As Lisa revives, Randy swings her guitar and clonks Mrs. Davis on the head.
scene.dialogue: 'We are all one spirit on Earth, one name.'
'We are the Father, we are the son, and in the Dawn of Creation we are one.'

scene.meta: Elaine enters with dinners.
scene.dialogue: Hey, we've been waiting for you. A little bit late tonight.
Who wants to be first?
Go ahead, Clarence, I got it.
scene.meta: Oveur removes his headset, Elaine puts tray down.
scene.dialogue: How's the weather?
Not so good. We've got some heavy stuff ahead of us. It might get rough again unless we can climb on top. But our airspeed is holding steady at six hundred ten knots.
That's great. By the way, Joey Hammen asked me if you would autograph this basketball.
scene.meta: Murdock autographs it reluctantly.
A JAPANESE GENERAL, dressed in World War II uniform, is now seated next to Striker.
scene.dialogue: After the war, I just wanted to get as far away from things as possible. So Elaine and I joined the Peace Corps. We were assigned to an isolated tribe, the Molombos.

scene.meta: Striker and Elaine are being escorted to the chief's hut by two GUARDS. We hear Jungle Animal SOUNDS. The chief is standing in front of his hut surrounded by several TRIBESMEN who are making the jungle animal sounds.
scene.dialogue: They had never seen Americans before.
scene.meta: When Striker and Elaine arrive, the CHIEF holds up his hands and the sounds stop.
scene.dialogue: At first, they didn't know what to think of us; but soon we gained their trust.
scene.meta: The Chief extends his right hand for conventional handshake. Striker shows him power grip. When the Chief is pleased, Striker gives him five. The Chief pauses then decks Striker.
scene.dialogue: It really was a challenge during the year introducing them to our Western culture.

scene.meta: Elaine is having a Supperware party for native women.
scene.dialogue: Also, Supperware products are ideal for storing leftovers to help stretch your food dollar. This two quart "Seals-M-Rite" container with a special "Close-M-Tite" lid keeps hotdog buns fresh for days and prevents sugared cereals from sticking.
scene.meta: She scoops a ladle of corn mush from a carved wooden bowl into a Supperware container.
scene.dialogue: Meat and dairy products are protected against unwanted refrigerator odors when sealed in this non-slip pastel colored "Freez-o-leer".
scene.meta: When she burps the lid, the Supperware makes a human burp SOUND.
Striker nailing crude basketball rim and net to tree.
scene.dialogue: You must understand that these people had been completely isolated from civilization.
scene.meta: Striker demonstrates a two-handed set shot to natives. He misses.
scene.dialogue: No one had ever outlined a physical fitness program for them and they had no athletic equipment.
scene.meta: Native examines basketball for first time. After two slow dribbles, he gracefully feints lefts, then, dribbling through his legs, sinks a two-hand, over-the-head, reverse dunk shot.
scene.dialogue: We also emphasized nutrition and taught them to watch their diets.
scene.meta: Another native hits a long jump shot.
scene.dialogue: The exercise improved their physical fitness and condition.
scene.meta: One shot after another swishes through the basketball rim.
scene.dialogue: My working with them seemed to reinforce our objectives of group cooperation and controlled-competitive activity.
scene.meta: Striker approaches Elaine who is standing on the sideline. As they talk, the natives are passing the ball around and shooting baskets Harlem Globetrotter fashion.
scene.dialogue: I think they're getting the hang of it! When we re-enlist I'll teach them baseball!
Ted, I don't want to stay here. It's time for us to go back home -- to the plans we made before the war.
A lot of people made plans before the war. Like George Zipp.
scene.meta: Elaine walks away, dejectedly. CAMERA STAYS with Striker as he pours Gator-Ade into a glass.
scene.dialogue: I guess it was at that moment that I first realized Elaine had doubts about our relationship. And that as much as anything else led to my drinking problem.
scene.meta: Striker has a problem drinking. He raises his glass of Gator-Ade, then suddenly pours it on his forehead.

scene.dialogue: We did come back to the States. I tried a number of jobs...Well, I could go on for hours, but I'd probably start to bore you.
scene.meta: The Japanese General is kneeling on the seat committing Hari Kari.
scene.dialogue: You know, I really couldn't blame Elaine. She wanted a career. I was offered a job at Boeing but I couldn't bring myself to take it...

scene.sceneheader: EXT. LAX PASSENGER LOADING AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: The businessman waiting in Striker's cab checks his watch.
THUNDER and lightning.
Shirley is ill and holding her stomach in pain.
scene.dialogue: Oh, I can't stand it.
What is it?
scene.meta: Elaine approaches.
scene.dialogue: Yes?
My, stomach. I haven't felt this awful since we saw that Lina Wertmuller film.
I'll see if I can find some Dramamine.
scene.meta: Elaine exits.
scene.dialogue: OOOOOO.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - STEWARDESS ALCOVE - NIGHT
scene.meta: Elaine is on the phone.
scene.dialogue: Captain, one of the women passengers is very sick.

scene.meta: Joey enters to retrieve basketball. Murdock is wearing goggles.
scene.dialogue: Airsick?
I think so, but I've never seen it so acute.
Find out if there's a doctor on board, as quietly as you can.
scene.meta: Oveur hangs up phone.
scene.dialogue: Joey, have you ever been in a Turkish prison?

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.dialogue: (nauseous) Oooh, I shouldn't have had that second cup of coffee.
scene.meta: He grabs for motion sickness bag. CAMERA ZOOMS to CLOSEUP of Mrs. Hammen.
scene.dialogue: Jim never vomits at home.

scene.meta: THUNDER and lightning.
Elaine is speaking to couple.
scene.dialogue: I'm sorry I had to wake you. I'm just looking for a doctor. There's nothing to worry about.
scene.meta: Middle-aged lady, MRS. YAFFE, having overheard this conversation, beckons to Elaine.
scene.dialogue: Stewardess, I think the man next to me is a doctor.
scene.meta: The MAN next to her is wearing a surgical cap with mask. Hanging around his neck is a stethoscope. He's sleeping.
scene.dialogue: Sir. Excuse me, sir. I'm sorry to have to wake you. Are you a doctor?
That's right.
We have some passengers who are very sick. Could you come and take a look at them?
Yes. Yes, of course.
scene.meta: Rumack picks up bag and exits with Elaine.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Rumack and Elaine enter. Rumack stoops over to Shirley, and surgical instrument is slapped into his hand from o.s. He pokes her stomach with his hand.
scene.dialogue: Pain there?
scene.meta: She winces and nods.
scene.dialogue: May I see your tongue, please?
scene.meta: She sticks her tongue out. Rumack pulls on it until it is obviously too long. He continues to pull, and the tongue becomes multi-colored magician's scarves. Then he pulls out a bouquet of flowers followed by a white dove.
scene.dialogue: I'll be back in a minute.
scene.meta: Rumack takes Elaine aside.
scene.dialogue: You'd better tell the Captain. We've got to land as soon as we can. This woman has to be gotten to a hospital.
A hospital? What is it?
It's a big building with patients. But that's not important right now. Tell the Captain I must speak to him.
Certainly.

scene.sceneheader: EXT. AIRPLANE - THUNDER AND LIGHTNING - NIGHT

scene.dialogue: (into mike) Thank you, Omaha. Two-zero-niner out. (to Basta) Victor, we're running into a heavy storm, can you...
scene.meta: Oveur turns to see Basta slumped over the console. Dramatic MUSIC.
scene.dialogue: Victor! Roger, take over!
scene.meta: Oveur lifts Basta onto ground.
THUNDER and lightning.
Murdock, flying the plane alone, wipes his brow and appears ill.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - OUTSIDE COCKPIT DOOR - NIGHT
scene.dialogue: Captain, how soon can we land?
I can't tell.
You can tell me. I'm a doctor!
No. I mean I'm just not sure.
Can't you take a guess?
Well...not for another two hours.
You can't take a guess for another two hours?
No, I mean we can't land for another two hours. Fog has closed down everything this side of the mountains. We've got to go through to Chicago!
scene.meta: Suddenly, the plane rocks violently. Rumack and Oveur lose balance.
THUNDER and lightning -- plane is flying erratically.
Murdock, unconscious, is slumped over controls. Oveur and Rumack burst into cockpit. Oveur gets into pilot's seat. Elaine enters.
scene.dialogue: (excitedly) Get him out of there!
Altitude is fluctuating.

scene.meta: Oveur struggles with controls. They extricate Murdock from behind the wheel. He is wearing shorts, kneepads, and basketball shoes.
climbing and diving.
Passengers are being tossed about. A woman, applying lipstick, smears it over her face.
scene.dialogue: -- cigarette with line slashed through, and couple copulating with line slashed through.

scene.meta: Randy loses her balance and shoves dinner into a passenger's face.
struggling with controls, finally regains level flight.
THUNDER and lightning -- plane levels off.
The St. Christopher statue is holding a motion discomtort bag to its mouth.
scene.dialogue: What is it, Doctor? What's happening?
I'm not sure. I haven't seen anything like this since the Lina Wertmuller Film Festival.
scene.meta: Rumack and Elaine are now standing face-to-face. Oveur, in the f.g., is at controls.
scene.dialogue: What was it we had for dinner tonight?
Well, we had a choice. Steak or fish.
Yes, yes, I remember. I had lasagna.
scene.meta: He points to Johnson.
scene.dialogue: What did he have?
He had fish.
scene.meta: Randy enters cockpit.
scene.dialogue: We have two more sick people, and the rest of the passengers are worried.
I'll take care of the passengers. Elaine, find out what the two sick people had for dinner. (into P.A.) This is Captain Oveur speaking.

scene.meta: Passengers are listening to P.A.
scene.dialogue: It's been a little bumpy up here but we'll be past it in a few minutes.
scene.meta: Randy and Elaine drag Murodck and Basta down center aisle.
scene.dialogue: A couple points of interest: we're just now passing over the Hoover Dam and later on, our course will take us just south of the Grand Canyon.
Meanwhile, relax and enjoy the rest of your flight. Okay? Okay!
scene.meta: He hangs up phone and turns to Rumack.
scene.dialogue: That should do it.

scene.meta: Absolute pandemonium. Passengers are yelling, screaming, tearing their hair out, climbing about.

scene.dialogue: (into microphone) Chicago, this is flight two-zero-niner. We're in trouble.

scene.sceneheader: INT. O'HARE WEATHER CENTER - CLOSEUP - TYPEWRITER - NIGHT
scene.meta: CAMERA PULLS OUT to reveal DISPATCHER typing Oveur's message.
scene.dialogue: We've got to have all altitudes below us cleared and priority approach and landing in Chicago. Over.
We read you. Stand by, two-zero-niner.
scene.meta: When he tries to remove paper from typewriter, it rips in half.
THUNDER and lightning.
Randy approaches Hammens. Mr. Hammen is sick.
scene.dialogue: Yes?
Oh, Stewardess. My husband is very sick. Can you do something, please?
Well, the doctor will be with you in just a moment. One thing: do you know what he had for dinner?
Yes, of course. We both had fish. Why?
Oh, it's nothing to be alarmed about. We'll get back to you very quickly.
scene.meta: She turns to walk toward CAMERA with horrified expression.
Elaine enters, turns to face Rumack. Oveur is at controls in f.g.
scene.dialogue: Doctor Rumack, Mister Hammen ate fish. And Randy says there are five more cases, and they ate fish, too.
Let's see now. The co-pilot had fish. What did the navigator eat?
He had fish, too.
scene.meta: Oveur is picking up on the conversation.
scene.dialogue: All right, now we know what we're up against. Every passenger on this plane who ate fish for dinner will become violently ill within the next half hour.
scene.meta: Oveur looks down at his dinner tray and sees skeleton of the fish he just ate.
scene.dialogue: Just how serious is it, doctor?
Extremely serious. It starts with a slight fever.
scene.meta: Oveur experiences what the doctor is describing.
scene.dialogue: Then a dryness in the throat. As the virus penetrates the red blood cells the victim becomes dizzy and begins to experience a rash and itching. From there the poison works its way into the central nervous system causing severe muscle spasms, followed by the inevitable drooling. At this point, the entire digestive system is rendered useless, causing the complete collapse of the lower bowels, accompanied by uncontrollable flatulence...until finally the poor bastard is reduced to a quivering, wasted piece of jelly.
scene.meta: Oveur passes out and pitches forward onto the controls. Rumack and Elaine lose balance as plane dives.
THUNDER and lightning as plane is diving.
Passengers are being tossed about. A woman, applying rouge, smears it all over her face.

scene.sceneheader: INT. CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - CLOSEUP - A PLATE OF JELLO
scene.meta: wiggling. CAMERA PANS UP to braless woman whose breasts are wiggling.
As they finally untangle Oveur from the wheel, he gains semi-consciousness.
scene.dialogue: (gasping) Turn...on...automatic pilot.
scene.meta: Oveur passes out.
scene.dialogue: Uh, automatic pilot...automatic pilot?
scene.meta: INSERT - ELAINE'S POV - CONTROL PANEL - NIGHT
scene.dialogue: is frantically searching for automatic pilot button.
There it is!
Elaine's hand tenuously reaches for and turns switch to "ON".

scene.meta: SOUND of rushing air as instantly inflatable balloon pilot takes shape in seat with hands on wheel. His uniform and cap are painted on, and he has an alert "leave the driving to us" expression on his face. The plane immediately regains level flight, and Elaine and Rumack sigh in relief.
scene.dialogue: I'll get back to the passengers.
scene.meta: Rumack exits. McCROSKEY (v.o.) (over radio) Come in two-zero-niner. This is Chicago. Flight two-zero-niner, come in, please. Elaine picks up mike while still standing.
scene.dialogue: This is Elaine Dickinson. I'm the stewardess. Captain Oveur is passed out on the floor, and we've lost the co-pilot and navigator, too. We're in terrible trouble. Over.
Groan!
scene.meta: McCROSKEY (v.o.) Elaine! Roger, Roger! I read you. This is Steve McCroskey at Chicago Air Control.
scene.dialogue: Hi, Steve!
scene.meta: McCROSKEY (v.o.) Now listen carefully. Is the automatic pilot on? Over.
scene.dialogue: Yes. Yes, it is. Over.
Huh?
scene.meta: McCROSKEY (v.o.) Very good. Now, Elaine, where are you? Over.
scene.dialogue: I'm standing over Oveur. Over.

scene.meta: McCROSKEY (into mike) All right, Elaine. Just hold on. We'll be back to you in a minute. CAMERA PULLS BACK to reveal dispatch is a beehive of activity. The Chief Dispatcher, STEVE McCROSKEY, is barking orders to AIR CONTROLLER #1. McCROSKEY Hold all takeoffs. I don't want another plane in the air. When the 508 reports, bring it straight in. Air Controller #1 exits quickly. McCroskey picks up phone. McCROSKEY Put out a general bulletin to suspend all meal service on flights out of Los Angeles. He hangs up phone and talks to AIR CONTROLLER #2. McCROSKEY Tell all dispatchers to remain at their posts. It's going to be a long night. Air Controller #2 exits. McCroskey notices he is out of coffee and turns to AIR CONTROLLER HINSHAW. McCROSKEY And how about some coffee, Johnny?
scene.dialogue: No thanks.
scene.meta: AIR CONTROLLER #3 enters. McCROSKEY I want the weather on every landing field on this side of the Rockies, no matter what the size. Air Controller #3 exits. AIR CONTROLLER #4 enters. McCROSKEY Do you understand? Air Controller #4 exits. AIR CONTROLLER #5 enters. McCROSKEY Any place where there's a chance to land this plane. Air Controller #5 exits. SIAMESE TWINS enter. McCROSKEY Stan, go upstairs to the tower and get a runway diagram. Terry, check down on the field for emergency equipment. Siamese Twins leave. In the b.g. we see them trying to walk in opposite directions. Air Controller #1 enters.
scene.dialogue: Chief, there's fog down to the deck everywhere east of the Rockies. There's no possible place they can land. They'll have to come through to Chicago.
scene.meta: McCROSKEY Looks like I picked the wrong week to quit smoking. He lights up a cigarette. McCroskey walks toward a table and leans on his hands. McCROSKEY I want the best available man on this. A man who knows this plane inside and out and won't crack under pressure.
scene.dialogue: How about Sal Mineo?
scene.meta: McCROSKEY Get me Rex Kramer!
Lightning and THUNDER.
Elaine is in the pilot's seat and the inflated automatic pilot is in co-pilot's seat. McCROSKEY (v.o.) Now, Elaine, right next to the throttle is the air speed gauge. What speed does it indicate?
scene.dialogue: Three hundred twenty miles per hour.
scene.meta: INSERT - AIR SPEED GAUGE
scene.dialogue: We see, but Elaine does not notice, the automatic pilot very slowly beginning to deflate.
scene.meta: McCROSKEY (v.o.) Good. Now check your altitude. That's the dial just below and to the right of the air speed indicator.
scene.dialogue: Thirty-five thousand feet.
Altitude is dropping.
scene.meta: BACK TO SCENE
scene.dialogue: No, wait. Now it says thirty-four thousand feet. It's dropping! It's dropping fast! Why is it doing that?
scene.meta: By now the automatic pilot is really slumped over as it is quite deflated. It is staring at her with a half smile. Elaine notices it.
scene.dialogue: Oh, my God! The automatic pilot! It's deflating!
scene.meta: McCROSKEY (v.o.) All right, Elaine, don't worry. We have an auxiliary inflation system. Just follow my instructions.
scene.dialogue: Okay, but please hurry! We're dropping fast!

scene.meta: Passengers are being tossed about. Rumack is examining a female patient.
scene.dialogue: What the hell's going on up there?
scene.meta: Rumack starts toward cockpit.
McCROSKEY (v.o.) Now, Elaine, don't panic. On the belt line of the automatie pilot there is a hollow tube. Can you see that?
scene.dialogue: Yes. Yes, I can see it.
scene.meta: McCROSKEY (v.o.) Good. Now that's the manual inflation nozzle. Pull it out and blow it up like a balloon. Elaine kneels over automatic pilot's crotch, puts tube in her mouth and blows. Automatic pilot inflates. Rumack bursts into cockpit.
scene.dialogue: Back of automatic pilot with Elaine kneeling over its crotch.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - OUTSIDE OF COCKPIT - NIGHT
scene.meta: Rumack slams the door in disbelief.
scene.dialogue: with a big smile on its face.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Passengers are relieved as plane regains level flight.

scene.sceneheader: EXT. AIRPLANE - THROUGH COCKPIT WINDOW - NIGHT
scene.meta: Elaine and automatic pilot are relaxed in their seats. Both are smoking cigarettes.
THUNDER and lightning.
Rumack enters.
scene.dialogue: Elaine, you're a member of this crew. Can you face some unpleasant facts?
No.
All right. Unless I can get all these people to a hospital quickly, I can't even be sure of saving their lives. Now, is there anyone else on board who can land this plane?
Well...

scene.meta: Striker, struggling with drinking problem, pours drink between his cheek and ear.

scene.dialogue: No. No one that I know of.

I think you ought to know what our chances are. The life of everyone on board depends on just one thing: finding someone back there who not only can fly this plane, but who didn't have fish for dinner.
scene.meta: CAMERA ZOOMS into CLOSEUP of Elaine's face as she realizes the severity of the situation.
THUNDER and lightning.
Passengers are listening to P.A.
scene.dialogue: Ladies and gentlemen, this is your stewardess speaking. We regret any inconvenience the sudden cabin movement might have caused.
scene.meta: Randy drags unconscious pilot, Oveur, down center aisle.
scene.dialogue: This is due to periodic air pockets we encounter. There is no reason to become alarmed, and we hope you enjoy the rest of your flight. By the way, is there anyone on ­board who knows how to fly a plane?
scene.meta: Absolute pandemonium. Passengers are yelling, screaming, tearing their hair out and climbing around. A naked woman runs down the aisle. Sister Mary is choking a Krishna. Two passengers are dueling with swords. A Spanish-speaking lady waits for her husband to translate the announcement, then panics.

SOUND of car screeching to a stop. PAUL CAREY, twenty-four year-old, cleancut, naive-looking, navigator trainee enters and pushes doorbell. We HEAR the typical eight-note chime progression. The CHIMES then play the Air Force Fight song. A dog BARKS and MRS. KRAMER opens the door.
scene.dialogue: Hello, I'm Paul Carey from the airline. I'm here to pick up Captain Kramer.
Oh, yes. Come in, Paul. Rex will be right out.

scene.meta: When Carey enters, a big dog jumps on him with its paws on his chest.
scene.dialogue: Shep, sit...sit! So, I understand you've got a real emergency down there.
(holding off dog) Well, to tell the truth, they really didn't fill me in on many of the details. Just told me to pick up Captain Kramer.
Something about a plane with no pilot?
scene.meta: Carey begins to lose battle with the dog, while trying to remain polite.
scene.dialogue: Yeah, something like that, but as I say, they didn't have time to tell me very much.
Shep, no! I'll bet you have exciting things happen all the time down there.
scene.meta: Shep is growling and Carey's arm is locked firmly in his Jaws.
scene.dialogue: Well...the airline business...does have... its moments...
scene.meta: Shep pins Carey against the wall, ripping his sleeve.
scene.dialogue: ...but after...awhile...you begin to... (gasp) ...get used to it.
Shep, no! He gets so excited when new people are here.
scene.meta: We hear a THUD and loud growling.
scene.dialogue: Are you a pilot yourself?
scene.meta: Carey is on the floor desperately fighting off the dog, which is on top of him.
scene.dialogue: I'm...in a...argh...navigator training program.
scene.meta: KRAMER enters, buttoning his coat.
scene.dialogue: It's unbelievable! How many times have I warned those people about food inspection?
scene.meta: Kramer is tying his tie in the mirror. In the corner of the mirror, Carey is being thrashed by the dog.
scene.dialogue: The airport management, the F.A.A., and the airlines, they're all cheats and liars! All right, let's get out of here.

scene.meta: THUNDER and lightning.
Randy is talking to Krishnas.
scene.dialogue: Sorry to bother you. We were just looking for someone with flying experience.
scene.meta: Randy exits. They return to reading their PLAYRAMA magazine with a female Hari Krishna in a sexy pose on the cover.
scene.dialogue: Hari Rama?
Rama Rama.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Striker is sitting next to a MAN FROM INDIA in a business suit and turban.
scene.dialogue: You see, the day we left the village it was raining, so we had to take a special jeep to the main road...
scene.meta: The Indian is dousing himself with a can of gasoline. In b.g. Randy is talking to passengers.
scene.dialogue: In fact, we were lucky to even get a jeep since just the day before the only one we had broke down -- it had a bad axle...
scene.meta: The Indian lights a match to immolate himself. Randy approaches.
scene.dialogue: Excuse me, sir. There's been a little problem in the cockpit and I was wondering...
The cockpit? What is it?

It's the little room at the front of the plane where the pilots sit. But that's not important right now. The first officer is ill and the Captain would like someone with flying experience to help him with the radio. Do you know anything about planes?
scene.meta: The Indian holds the match, awaiting the outcome.
scene.dialogue: Well, I flew in the war, but that was a long time ago. I wouldn't know anything about it.
Would you go up, please?
scene.meta: He has a moment of indecision. The Indian encourages Striker with an adamant nod. Striker gets up to leave. The Indian, relieved, blows out the match.

scene.sceneheader: INT. PASSENGER CABIN - ANOTHER AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: Jack is sitting across the aisle from a 65-year-old con­servatively dressed SPINSTER. He pulls a flask from his coat pocket and takes a swig. She eyes him dis­approvingly.
scene.dialogue: Would ya like a little whiskey, ma'am?
(insulted) Certainly not.
scene.meta: She inserts a two inch straw in her nose and snorts a couple lines of cocaine off a piece of glass.
Striker enters.
scene.dialogue: (to Rumack and Randy) The stewardess said...
Empty pilot's seat and inflated automatic pilot.
Both pilots!
Can you fly this airplane and land it?
Surely you can't be serious.
I am serious, and don't call me Shirley! What flying experience have you had?
Well, I flew single-engine fighters in the Air Force, but this plane has four engines. It's an entirely different kind of flying...all together!!!
(all together) It's an entirely different kind of flying.
Besides, I haven't touched any ­kind of plane in six years.
Mister Striker. I know nothing about flying. All I know is this: you're the only person on this plane who can possibly fly it. You're the only chance we've got.
scene.meta: DRAMATIC MUSIC as Striker turns to face the controls.
scene.dialogue: CAMERA PANS controls. CAMERA KEEPS PANNING and PANNING as WE SEE more and more controls ad absurdum.

scene.sceneheader: EXT. LAX PASSENGER LOADING AREA - NIGHT
scene.meta: INSERT METER - $ll5.25. The businessman in Striker's cab checks his watch.

McCROSKEY (to Air Controller) Tell Omaha to acknowledge and standby. (into phone) Get every piece of emergency equipment you can reach. (to Air Controller) Alert at every mile of the way from here to the mountains. Hinshaw grabs Air Controller #1's tummy.
scene.dialogue: Would anyone care for a roll and coffee?
scene.meta: Phone RINGS.
scene.dialogue: Chief?
scene.meta: McCROSKEY We'll need a pre-landing flight check. Tell 'em I'm in the dispatch office and I want it here fast.
scene.dialogue: It's your wife.
scene.meta: McCROSKEY (into phone) I want the kids in bed by nine. I want the dog fed, the yard watered, and the gate locked. And get a note to the milkman -- no more cheese! He slams dowm the phone. He leans his hands on the desk. McCROSKEY Where the hell is Kramer? On the wall behind him there is a picture of McCroskey leaning his hands on a desk.
Kramer and a mutilated Carey are en route to airport. Kramer is at the wheel. Through rear window is obvious REAR PROJECTION of passing road.
scene.dialogue: (into phone) No, we can't do that; the risk of a flameout is too great. Keep him 24,000. No, feet!
scene.meta: He hangs up phone.
scene.dialogue: One of the passengers is going to land that plane.
Is that possible?
Possible, but it's a hundred to one shot. Thousand to one. I know this guy.
You do? Who is it?
scene.meta: We hear A THUNK. REAR PROJECTION shows he has run oyer a bicyclist, who stands and gives the finger.
scene.dialogue: His name is Ted Striker. I flew with him during the war. And that won't make my job any easier tonight.
scene.meta: REAR PROJECTION SPEEDS UP to obvious FAST MOTION.
scene.dialogue: Ted Striker was a crack flight leader up to a point. But he was one of those men who, well, let's just say he felt too much inside. Maybe you know the kind.
scene.meta: Now REAR PROJECTION indicates car is turning and then weaving, but Kramer does not move wheel.
scene.dialogue: It takes a certain type to perform under pressure. Striker didn't have it.
scene.meta: By now REAR PROJECTION is cowboys and Indians on horseback chasing and shooting at Kramer's car.
scene.dialogue: Ate his heart out over every name on the casualty lists. The upshot of it is that he went all to pieces on one particular mission. Let's just hope it doesn't happen again tonight.

scene.meta: THUNDER and lightning.
Striker is in pilot's seat. Rumack is standing behind him.
scene.dialogue: Let's see, altitude twenty-four thousand feet, level flight, air speed four hundred sixty knots, course zero niner zero, trim, mixture, landing gear, balance.
scene.meta: Elaine enters.
scene.dialogue: Ted! What are you doing? You can't fly this plane!
That's what I've been trying to tell these people.
Elaine, I haven't time to put this gently, so I'll be very direct. Everyone of us on this plane is in a desperate situation. Mister Striker is the only hope we've got.
Let's see. Those are the flaps, that's the thrust, this must turn on the landing lights.
scene.meta: He flips a switch. The plane dives.
The plane is diving.
Jack is standing at toilet. He is jolted back and forth against the walls.
scene.dialogue: flashing: RETURN TO SEAT
scene.meta: GOBACKEN SIDONNA

scene.dialogue: (into mike) Mayday!
Mayday! Mayday!
scene.meta: McCROSKEY (surprised) Mayday? What the hell is that for?
scene.dialogue: It's the Russian New Year! We'll have a parade! They'll serve hot hors d'oeuvres!

scene.meta: Striker flips switch and rights plane.
Level flight.
McCROSKEY (v.o.) Two-zero-niner, are you okay up there?
scene.dialogue: Yeah, I was just trying out the landing lights.
scene.meta: Elaine and Rumack exchange glances.

scene.dialogue: I've got to get out of here! I can't stand it! I've got to get out of here!
scene.meta: Randy pushes up and shakes Mrs. Hammen by the shoulders.
scene.dialogue: Calm down. Get hold of yourself!
Stewardess, let me handle this.
scene.meta: Randy leaves, Jack shakes Mrs. Hammen by the shoulders.
scene.dialogue: Get hold of yourself! Get hold of yourself!
(to Jack) Get back to your seat; I'll take care of this.
scene.meta: Jack leaves; Rumack shakes Mrs. Hammen by the shoulders.
scene.dialogue: Calm down. Calm down. Get hold of yourself!
scene.meta: Sister Angelina taps Rumack on the shoulder.
scene.dialogue: (to Rumack) Doctor, you're wanted on the phone.
scene.meta: Sister Angelina starts shaking Mrs. Hammen.
scene.dialogue: Everything will be all right. Please get hold of yourself.
scene.meta: We see a line of passengers behind Sister Angelina waiting to shake Mrs. Hammen.
reads: CHICAGO INTERNATIONAL AIRPORT
OVER 16 BILLION PLANES LANDED
As Kramer rushes through the lobby, he is approached by a series of religious zealots. In quick succession he decks each one karate style, shooting the last zealot twenty feet away with a .44 Magnum.

scene.sceneheader: INT. TERMINAL BUILDING - LONG SHOT - NIGHT
scene.dialogue: Your attention, please. Flight four-one- seven now departing the B Concourse, gate six.
Your attention, please. Flight twenty- seven now arriving the B Concourse, gate six.
scene.meta: There is a LOUD CRASH, and the SCENE SHAKES.

scene.dialogue: (into phone) This guy doing the flying has no airline experience at all. He'll be a menace to himself and everything else in the air... (he pauses to listen) ...Yes, birds too.
scene.meta: Kramer enters, picks up clipboard, and reads it. McCROSKEY (into phone) Okay, okay. He's a terrible risk, but what other choice have we got? McCroskey hangs up phone. McCROSKEY Well, that's the whole story, Rex, everything we know.
scene.dialogue: All right, Steve, let's face a few facts.
scene.meta: Kramer whips off his sunglasses. Underneath is another pair of sunglasses.
scene.dialogue: As you know, I flew with this man, Striker, during the war. He'll have enough on his mind without remembering those days when -- well, when things weren't so good.
scene.meta: McCROSKEY Well, right now things aren't so good. And while we're talking there are a hundred and thirty-eight lives waiting on us for a decision.
scene.dialogue: Let me tell you something, Steve. Striker was a top-notch squadron leader -- a long time ago...
scene.meta: A spear slams into the wall behind Kramer.
scene.dialogue: ...but my feeling is that when the going gets rough upstairs tonight, Ted Striker's gonna fold up.
scene.meta: McCROSKEY Look, Rex -- I want you to get on the horn and talk this guy down! You're going to have to let him get the feel of this airplane on the way; you'll have to talk him onto the approach; and so help me, you'll have to talk him right down to the ground! A watermelon falls from TOP OF FRAME, splattering on the table.
scene.dialogue: Very well then. Put Striker on the speaker.
scene.meta: McCROSKEY Okay, you can use the radio over there. Looks like I picked the wrong week to quit drinking. He pulls a flask trom the drawer and takes a swig.
Kramer at dispatch radio. He picks up mike.
scene.dialogue: Striker, Striker, this is Captain Rex Kramer speaking.
scene.meta: McCroskey joins Kramer at dispatch radio.
DRAMATIC MUSIC as we see Striker's ominous look of recognition.
scene.dialogue: (dramatically) Yes, Captain Kramer. Read you loud and clear.

scene.meta: Kramer sits at the mike. An Air Controller is standing next to him, but only his mid-section is in FRAME.
scene.dialogue: All right. It's obvious you remember me.
scene.meta: The Air Controller is scratching his behind.
scene.dialogue: So what do you say you and I just forget about everything except what we have to do now?
scene.meta: The Air Controller is now scratching his crotch.
scene.dialogue: You and I are going to bring this plane in together.
scene.meta: The Air Controller's hand is now inside his pants straightening out his underwear.
scene.dialogue: Before we start, I'd like to say something. I know that right now things must look pretty rough up there.
scene.meta: The Air Controller is now hopping around with both hands inside his pants.
scene.dialogue: But if you do what I tell you, when I tell you to do it, there's no reason you can't bring that plane in.
Let's not kid each other, Kramer. You know I've never flown a bucket like this. I'm going to need all the luck there is.

Stand by, Striker. (to McCroskey) The one hope we have is to build this man up. I've got to give him all the confidence I can. (into microphone) All right, Striker, have you ever flown a multi-engine plane before?
No. Never.
Shit!

scene.meta: Striker over hears conversation on radio.
scene.dialogue: This is a goddamn waste of time. There's no way he can land this plane! Route 'em into Lake Michigan and at least avoid killing innocent people!

scene.meta: McCROSKEY Grab hold of yourself! You've got to talk them down. You're the only chance they've got! Kramer lights cigarette.
scene.dialogue: (into mike) All right, Striker, now you listen to me and you listen close. Flying is no different than riding a bicycle...it just happens to be a lot harder to put baseball cards in the spokes. Now, if you just follow my instructions...

scene.meta: Two vultures are sitting on back of Striker's seat.
scene.dialogue: ...there's no reason why you shouldn't have complete confidence in your chances to come out of this thing alive and in one piece.
First, I want you to familiarize yourself with the controls. Later we'll run through the landing procedure.
scene.meta: Kramer takes a last drag on his cigarette and tosses it out the window. McCroskey plugs his ears with his fingers and ducks as though Kramer had thrown a grenade. There is an EXPLOSION O.S.
scene.dialogue: All right. Now I'd like you to disengage the automatic pilot. But watch any violent movement of the controls, like you used to make in Spitfires and Phantoms.
(into microphone) Okay, I'm going to unlock the automatic pilot.
scene.meta: Striker switches off automatic pilot button. Automatic pilot shoots upward out of the seat. Elaine is thrown to the floor. Striker struggles desperately to control the plane.
flying erratically.

scene.dialogue: (matter of factly) Just remember, the controls will feel very heavy compared to a fighter.
scene.meta: Striker is fighting the wheel and the autopilot which is drifting in his way. Finally, he throws the autopilot to the rear of the cockpit.
scene.dialogue: Don't worry about that. It's perfectly normal. You must watch your airspeed closely. Don't let it fall below 520. Both your rudder pedals and elevator trim will have additional play due to increased drag, but you can compensate by lowering manifold pressure below 154. Now there's one other thing. Have you someone up there who can work the radio and leave you free for flying?
Yes! The stewardess is here with me!
scene.meta: Elaine rises. The autopilot is on her back, its hands clinging to her breasts. She removes it and seats it at engineer's console.
scene.dialogue: Have her take the co-pilot's seat.
scene.meta: Elaine takes her seat as Striker regains control of the plane. He hands Elaine the mike.
scene.dialogue: The radio's all yours now. And keep an eye on that number three engine. It's running a little hot.
A LITTLE HOT is blinking.
scene.meta: BACK TO

scene.dialogue: Striker, what kind of weather are you in up there?
(into microphone) Rain.
And a little ice.
And a little ice!
How's it handling?
Sluggish. Like a wet sponge.
(into microphone) Sluggish. Like a wet sponge.
(patronizing) All right, Striker, you're doing just fine.
(to Elaine) It's a damn good thing he doesn't know how much I hate his guts.
(into microphone) It's a damn good thing you don't know how much he hates your guts.

scene.meta: A Black Dude is holding his stomach in pain.
scene.dialogue: Oooooooh.
scene.meta: Randy approaches.
scene.dialogue: Can I get something for you?
Cain fo' gwine sho fi cun for.
I'm sorry. I don't understand.
scene.meta: MRS. SCHIFF, a middle-aged woman, is seated behind the Black Dudes.
scene.dialogue: Oh, stewardess, I can speak jive. He said he's in great pain and wants to know if you can help him.
Tell him to relax and I'll be back as quickly as I can with some medicine.
scene.meta: Randy exits.
scene.dialogue: Shi gwine man chitlun down for mo sho.
(indignantly) Shi man I ain neba mo fo gwine ain.
scene.meta: They engage in an argument in jive talk, with Mrs. Schiff getting the best of it. She swaggers off in typical black dude fashion.
Sister Angelina is singing to the Krishnas.
scene.dialogue: '...I sit by the telephone for hours. I love when men send me flowers. I enjoy being a girl.'

scene.meta: Jack is comforting an ailing Shirley. She is per­spiring.
scene.dialogue: How ya doing, honey?
Oh Jack, I'm so warm. I'm burning up.
Here.
scene.meta: He reaches up and opens the overhead air nozzle. Air rushes out with hurricane force. As Jack struggles to turn off nozzle, Shirley is blown about, an adjacent passenger's papers go flying from a briefcase, a Hari Krishna's toga flies up revealing polka dot boxer shorts. An extra's toupe flies off.
SOFT MUSIC.
scene.dialogue: After my wife died, I felt like a fifth wheel. You know, so many years being with one person -- a very wonderful person -- makes you always think of yourself as part of a pair...When Ethel passed away, I was lost. I couldn't function socially and I couldn't function in business.
Well, after a thing like that you wouldn't be expected to.
But I think it's time we stopped talking about me. A woman like you -- why haven't you ever married?
Well, I'm afraid that's a question that's all too easy to answer.
I know the answer -- Career. A smart woman like you became so involved in your work, you didn't have time for marriage.
I wish I could fool myself into believing that that's the reason. The truth of the matter is, nobody ever asked me.
You know, here we are having coffee together, and discussing education and business and economy...and we don't even know each other's names...full names I mean.
Mine's Eleanor. Eleanor Schiff.
That's a lovely name. Mine's Milton...Milt Ettenhenim. But my friends call me 'Bubbles.'

scene.meta: Randy approaches Mrs. Schiff.
scene.dialogue: Would you care for a soft drink?
I'd be glad to.
scene.meta: Randy hands a large bottle of Coca Cola wrapped in a baby blanket to Ms. Schiff, who cradles it in her arms.
scene.dialogue: Ooooh, such a nice soft drink.

scene.sceneheader: INT. O'HARE WEATHER CENTER - CLOSEUP ON TYPEWRITER
scene.meta: CAMERA PULLS OUT to reveal Dispatcher typing message.
scene.dialogue: National Weather Service reporting Omaha fogged in. Visibility zero.
scene.meta: The Dispatcher attempts to remove the message, but it is stuck in the cartridge. He yanks on it, but the paper stretches out like rubber. The scene now becomes like a cartoon. He lodges his feet against the typewriter and pulls until the paper stretches to his face. He grumbles in Donald Duck voice. The typewriter snaps back and hits him.

McCROSKEY (to Air Controller #2) Macias, get me Captain Oveur's wife on the phone. We'd better let her know what's going on. Air Controller #1 rushes in holding a piece of paper and hands it to McCroskey.
scene.dialogue: Steve, this weather bulletin just came off the wire.
scene.meta: McCroskey frowns and hands it to Hinshaw. McCROSKEY Johnny, what can you make out of this?
scene.dialogue: This? Why, I could make a hat or a broach...
scene.meta: McCroskey grabs the note from him.
MRS. OVEUR is in bed. Phone on night table RINGS. She reaches for it sleepily.
scene.dialogue: Hello?
Missus Oveur?
Yes, this is Missus Oveur.
This is Ed Macias calling from the airport. There's some trouble on your husband's flight.
scene.meta: SHOT WIDENS to reveal she is sleeping with a horse.
scene.dialogue: We don't know how serious it is yet, but Harry Ballard thought you'd want to get down here right away.
I'll be right down.
scene.meta: She hangs up the phone and rises.
scene.dialogue: I've got to go to the airport. You can let yourself out the back door. There's juice in the refrigerator.
(sounding like Mr. Ed) Did you finish? Was I good?
Oh, you're all so concerned about performance!

scene.meta: THUNDER and lightning; turbulent weather.
Randy approaches Mrs. Schiff, who is caring for a drink.
scene.dialogue: Would you care for another drink?
No, thank you, I'm still nursing this one.
scene.meta: She is bottle feeding the Coke bottle.
scene.dialogue: (to bottle) There, just a little bit more -- and then burpie time and a good nap!

scene.meta: Elaine hangs up phone.
scene.dialogue: Doctor Rumack says the sick people are getting worse and we're running out of time.
scene.meta: Striker is perspiring.
scene.dialogue: (echoing) I've got to concentrate, concentrate, entrate, I've got to concentrate, oncentrate, oncentrate.
scene.meta: He becomes aware of ECHO.
scene.dialogue: (echoing) Hell, hello, ello, ello, ello, lo, lo. Echo, echo, echo, cho, cho, o, o, o, o, o. Pinch hitting for Pedro Bourbone, Manny Mota, Mota, Mota, Mota.

scene.meta: Nose dowm.
scene.dialogue: (hysterically) Ted, the altitude! We're falling, we're falling!
scene.meta: INSERT - GAUGE INDICATING DROPPING ALTITUDE
THUNDER and lightning. Flying nose down.
A Woman applying eye makeup, smears it over her face.

DRAMATIC MUSIC as Striker is struggling with the con­trols. Windshield wipers are moving as though directing music. St. Christopher statue is holding an umbrella. Striker regains control of the plane.

scene.dialogue: (to Rumack) What's going on? We have a right to know the truth!
(to passengers) All right. I'm going to level with you. The most important thing now is that you should all be calm, because there's no reason to panic.
scene.meta: Rumack's nose elongates slightly.
scene.dialogue: Now, it is true that one of the flight crew has been taken ill...slightly ill.
scene.meta: His nose is getting longer.
scene.dialogue: But the other two pilots are just fine and at the controls flying the plane.
scene.meta: Rumack's nose is a foot long.
scene.dialogue: The weather in Chicago is clear as a bell, and there's no reason that we won't land on schedule...
Passengers listening. His nose grows THROUGH FRAME.
...safe and sound and free to pursue a life of religious fulfillment.
(into microphone) Chicago, the passengers are beginning to panic. When do we start down?
(into microphone) Not just yet, we'll have you in radar range any second now.

scene.sceneheader: EXT. O'HARE AIRPORT - REVOLVING RADAR ANTENNA - NIGHT

scene.dialogue: (to McCroskey) I don't understand it. He should have been in range ten minutes ago.
scene.meta: McCROSKEY (into microphone) Gunderson, check the radar range. Anything yet?
GUNDERSON opens door of Amana Radar Range and peers in. There is a turkey inside.
scene.dialogue: (into microphone) About two more minutes, Chief.

scene.meta: McCROSKEY Two more minutes! They could be miles off course.
scene.dialogue: That's impossible. They're on instruments!

scene.meta: Elaine, Randy, Rumack, and Striker are playing trumpet, clarinet, saxophone and bass fiddle in Benny Goodman swing band style.

scene.dialogue: This is gonna be a real sweat. (into mike) Gunderson, let me know when you get anything.
scene.meta: McCROSKEY I can't take much more of this! Johnny, how about some more coffee?
scene.dialogue: Would you like half of my provolone and roast beef?
